comments: Originally marketed as an Italo-disco duo formed by Pezzali and Repetto, their albums often feature electronic, disco-friendly songs as well as romantic, radio-friendly ballads. Repetto left the group in 1994 and eventually retired from the music business; since then, Pezzali has been the only official member of the band.

name: Jon Lord
comments: An accomplished classical composer as well as rock musician, Lord created a signature keyboard sound with a combination of Hammond B3 and C3 organs and Leslie speakers.  His playing was prominent in bands such as the Artwoods, the Flowerpot Men, Paice Ashton & Lord and Whitesnake but he will likely be best remembered for his playing and composition in Deep Purple and his solo classical projects.

name: Joe Becker
comments: Drummer from San Francisco, CA. Originally from Madison, WI. He was an important figure in the flourishing Davis, CA eighties music scene. He started with Alternate Learning, a power pop/new wave band. Then he joined power pop/jangle pop band Game Theory, followed by a brief stint in the Paisley Underground band True West. He was the drummer of the desert rock band Thin White Rope from 1984 until the end of the eighties, before joining the power pop band The Loud Family.

name: Keigo Oyamada
comments: Trendsetting musician, songwriter, singer and producer. After his band Flipper's Guitar disbanded, he chose to adopt the moniker "Cornelius" (a character from "The Planet of the Apes"). In the 1990's, Oyamada was a key figure in the popularization of the Shibuya-kei (Shibuya style) both in Japan and abroad, through an incessant activity of discovery, promotion, production and support to fellow indie artists, most of which were signed to his own label Trattoria . His early works were influenced by indie pop, noise rock and sunshine pop, whereas his later works are more electronic, abstract, and experimental. His sources of inspiration are often explicitly referenced in his songs and in the artworks of his albums.

comments: Soul and R&B music singer and actor

name: Owen Bradley
aliases: Owen Bradley and His Orchestra – Vocal by The Bradettes
Owen Bradley and His Ragland Band
comments: Owen Bradley was a musician, songwriter, arranger and record producer from Tennessee. He was one of the architects of the "Nashville Sound." In 1930 he quit high school to play music with Farris Coursey's Blue Diamond Melody Boys. By the 1940s he was a regular on WSM and was producing records for Decca in Nashville. In 1949 he produced one of his first big hits,  Red Foley's "Chattanooga Shoe Shine Boy." It featured his former "boss," Farris Coursey, slapping his thigh to recreate the sound of a rhythmic shoeshiner's rag. Bradley was head of Decca's Nashville division from 1958 until 1976. Owen Bradley and his brother, Harold, built an independent recording studio in Nashville in the 1950s. Known as Bradley's Barn it was the site for 700 recording sessions annually in the early 1960s. He was inducted into the Country Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1974.

name: Marvin Hughes

He eventually left to pursue the more lucrative work of composing, being named on a number of popular albums of the 1940's and 1950's. He also composed the original themes for the films "The Blue Hour" (1971) and "Return to Campus" (1975).

comments: Industrial band formed in New Mexico

name: DB9D9
comments: Industrial band based in San Diego, California.

name: Hotbox
comments: Punk band based in Northern California.

name: Jonathan Sharp
comments: Electro/industrial artist based in Cumbria. New Mind is his original solo project which begun in 1990. Bio-Tek is an industrial project.

name: The WFG All-Stars
comments: Part of Waiting for God, a goth/industrial band based in Vancouver.

name: John Bergin
comments: Industrial/darkwave artist and graphic novel artist.

name: Bella Donna
comments: Stevie Nicks tribute band -- both solo and with Fleetwood Mac.

name: Ty England
comments: Country music singer and guitarist born in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, who started out as a member of Garth Brooks' band and then went solo in 1995.

name: Gérard Klein
comments: Actor, radio host, singer and producer

name: Black Tide
comments: Heavy metal band from Miami, FL

name: SSIK
comments: Kiss cover band from Austin, Texas.  They do not wear Kiss make-up.

name: Leon McAuliffe
aliases: Leon McAuliff and His Cimarron Boys
Leon McAuliffe and His Swingin' Western Band
Leon McAuliffe & His Western Swing Band
Leon McAuliffe and His Western Swing Band
comments: Country musician (guitar, slide steel guitar), vocalist and songwriter

name: Skitch Henderson
aliases: Skitch Henderson, His Piano and His Orchestra
comments: Conductor, pianist and radio and television entertainer who provided music for the "Tonight" show in the 1950's and 1960's and who founded and led The New York Pops.

name: George F. Root
comments: Songwriter, particularly popular for his Civil War songs. Inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1970

name: Alderliefste
comments: Band from Amsterdam around frontman Gerard Jan Alderliefste (lead vocals and guitar)

name: Member U-0176
comments: Keyboardist. Thee Hyphen is his solo synth project.

name: Libitina
comments: Gothic darkwave band from Sheffield. Formed in 1994 and split up in September 2006

name: Alien 6
comments: Electronica project by Geoff Pinckney. It includes former members of The Nine.

name: Nico Wieditz
comments: Electro artist based in Eisenach. Syntphonic is a neoclassical synth project.

name: Reeves Gabrels
comments: Guitarist, vocalist, songwriter, producer and more. Best known for collaborating with David Bowie throughout the 1990s.

name: Samuel Smiles
comments: Ambient music band, frequently referred to as "Tim Bowness/Samuel Smiles". Members: Michael Bearpark, Myke Clifford, Peter Chilvers.

name: Buster Bloodvessel
comments: Singer and front man for Bad Manners.

name: King Black Acid
comments: Psychedelic/space rock group from Portland, Oregon

name: Spurge
comments: Alternative rock band from Billings, Montana. They later relocated to Portland, Oregon

name: The Chords [GB]
comments: South East London mod revival band

name: Mrs. Miller
comments: Singer who gained some fame in the 1960s for her series of shrill and off-key renditions of then-popular songs.

name: The Peppermint Rainbow
comments: American sunshine pop group from Baltimore, Maryland consisting of Bonnie and Patty Lamdin (vocals), Doug Lewis (guitar), Anton Corey (percussion) and Skip Harris (bass).

name: Dudley Manlove Quartet
comments: The Dudley Manlove Quartet is actually a quintet, and none of its members is named "Dudley Manlove".  The band performs covers of popular music songs.

name: Rex Griffin
comments: Country music performer from 1930 until the late-1940s and songwriter.  (Griffin continued songwriting after he stopped personal performance.)  Griffin contracted tuberculosis in the mid-1950s.

name: Benny Anderssons orkester
comments: Big band performing Swedish traditional style songs

name: Mats Nörklit
comments: Malmö born writer, lyricist, composer and musician

name: Dooley Wilson
comments: Actor and singer, best known for his role as "Sam" the piano player in the movie "Casablanca" (1942).

name: Jacques Renard
aliases: Jacques Renard and His Cocoanut Grove Orchestra
comments: Russian-born violinist from Kiev. In the 1920s he led orchestras in the Boston area, which eventually led to his conducting radio studio orchestras.

name: Jimmie Grier
comments: Jazz clarinetist, songwriter, composer, arranger and bandleader from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. He worked with Abe Lyman, George Stoll and Gus Arnheim groups. He recorded for Brunswick, Columbia and Decca Records.

name: Buddy Clark [US1]
comments: Pop and big band vocalist. Clark's voice was dubbed in several movies of the 1930s and 1940s for non-singing Hollywood actors.

name: Devin Johnson
comments: One of the kids that is part of the SpongeBob SquarePants theme song chorus.

name: Stephen Hillenburg
comments: Animator, cartoonist, writer and producer best known for creating SpongeBob SquarePants

name: Tok Tok Tok
comments: Mainly a duo with two quite permanent co-musicians playing what has been described as 'Fine Arts Soul Jazz': Tokunbo Akinro (vocals) & Morten Klein (tenor saxophone, guitar, drums, mouth percussion) plus Christian Flohr (double & electric bass), Jens Gebel (Fender Rhodes & other keys), Matthias Meusel (drums).

name: Steve Rizzo
comments: Producer from Rhode Island, owner of the "Stable Sound Studio", based in Portsmouth, Rhode Island

name: Athlete
comments: Indie rock band formed in Deptford, London

name: The Yockamo All-Stars
comments: Grouping of musicians based in New Orleans

name: Pete Best
comments: Drummer and vocalist, best known for being dismissed from 'The Beatles' for his limited drumming abilities immediately prior to the band achieving worldwide fame

name: New Colony Six
comments: Soft rock band from Chicago. Active: 1964 - 1974.

name: Ian Stewart [GB1]
comments: "Stu" (as everyone knew him) was a British keyboardist and co-founder of The Rolling Stones. He was dismissed from the line-up in May 1963 but he remained as road manager and contributed piano, organ, marimbas and percussion to all Rolling Stones albums released between 1964 and 1986.

name: Harry Johnson
comments: Record producer, label owner and musician

name: The Sharks [GB1]
comments: Rockabilly band formed in the late 1970s

name: Sunnyboys
comments: Post-punk, alternative rock and power pop band

name: Henry Clay Work
comments: Very popular nineteenth century songwriter and composer. He was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame as part of its inaugural class in 1970. Work and his family were passionate abolitionists from Connecticut; their family home was a stop on the Underground Railway for which Work's father had been imprisoned for a time. Work wrote several emotional Civil War songs, and his "Marching Through Georgia" is considered to be one of the great Civil War songs of the North.

name: Purr Machine
comments: Electropop duo based in Los Angeles.

name: John Raitt
comments: Actor-singer best known for his roles on Broadway

name: Joe LaBarbera
comments: Jazz drummer, composer and music educator.  LaBarbera has taught at the California Institute of the Arts since 1993.  He is probably best known as the drummer in the Bill Evans Trio at the time of Evans' death in 1980.

name: Tom Warrington
comments: Jazz acoustic and electric bassist.  Warrington is also a composer.

name: Deerhoof
comments: Indie rock band formed and based in in San Francisco

name: Los Campesinos!
comments: Indie pop band founded in Cardiff, Wales

name: Kathleen Hanna
comments: Rock vocalist based in Portland, Oregon

name: Tobi Vail
comments: American musician, music critic and feminist from Olympia, Washington

name: I tubi lungimiranti
comments: Beat group founded in 1964 from the Marche region in Italy.

name: The Rhythm Wreckers
comments: Studio band for XELO. a border radio station in Tijuana, Mexico

name: Texas Lightning
comments: Country and pop quintet from Hamburg known for humour-esque performances. Most members used nick names.

name: James Monroe
comments: Bluegrass music singer, producer, guitarist and bassist.

name: Hunters & Collectors
comments: Style evolved from early art-funk before a bass and drum driven pub rock phase and finally guitar driven pop rock

name: Mark Seymour
comments: Guitarist and singer. He started out with the post-punk band The Jetsonnes in 1980, was the frontman and singer of the rock band Hunters & Collectors from 1981 until 1998, and is performing as a solo artist since then.

name: Jimmy Diggs
comments: One half of The Knight Brothers.

name: Sunny & The Sunliners
comments: Latino rhythm and blues band from San Antonio, Texas, fronted and managed by Sunny Ozuna

name: Versailles [1]
comments: Dark wave/synthpop artist from Los Angeles, California

name: The Amazing Dancing Band
comments: Studio session covers group with Laurie Holloway (piano), Max Harris (piano), Eddie Blair (trumpet), Neill Sanders (horn), Ronnie Verrell (drums)

name: Akatuki
comments: Rock band consisting of Takushi Suda (Vocals), Satoshi Aoki (Guitar), Katoki Tsukasa (Bass) and Tetsushi Takai (Drums).

name: Swingin' Utters
aliases: Johnny Peebucks and The Swingin' Utters

name: Lou Martin
comments: British pianist, keyboardist and organist, born in Belfast, Northern Ireland

name: Tom Lewis [GB]
comments: A former submariner in the British Royal Navy who sings sea shanties.

name: Lydia
comments: Indo-rock singer from Amersfoort, active at the end of the 1950s and early 1960s

name: Joan Weber
comments: Joan Weber was born in Paulsboro, New Jersey. Her recording of "Let Me Go, Lover" was introduced on an episode of the Studio One network television show which aired on November 15, 1954. It was played six times during the broadcast creating huge demand for her recording. By December 4, 1954 her recording entered the Billboard charts where it soon rose to the top position. She never repeated her chart success and, unfortunately, Joan died at age 45 in the Ancora Psychiatric Hospital in southern New Jersey.

name: Pete Sinfield
comments: Songwriter, poet and artist. He is best known for his contributions to King Crimson and Emerson, Lake & Palmer.

name: Brian May [GB]
comments: Guitarist, songwriter and occasional singer.  May also has obtained a doctorate degree in astrophysics in which field he has published scholarly papers.

name: Rick Parfitt
comments: Singer, rhythm guitarist and songwriter. Along with fellow band member Francis Rossi he was appointed an Officer of the Order of the British Empire (OBE) in the New Years Honours 2010.

name: Jackie Lynton
comments: Musician (guitar), singer, songwriter and producer, born in Shepperton, Middlesex

name: Andy Bown
comments: Rock multi-instrumentalist, including guitar, bass, and keyboards. Bown also sings.

name: Ray Davies [GB1]
comments: Musician (guitar, harmonica, keyboards and piano), lead singer, songwriter and record producer

name: Randy Bachman
comments: Songwriter, guitarist, and producer, who was the driving force behind the formation of two leading Canadian rock bands, and an influential rock songwriter.

name: Burton Cummings
comments: Singer, songwriter and keyboardist.  On December 30, 2009, Cummings was made an officer in the Order of Canada, one of Canada's highest civilian honors.  He now spends his time between southern California and Winnipeg where he grew up.

name: Phil Medley
aliases: Phil Medley and The MVB Orchestra & Chorus
comments: Songwriter and strings and horns orchestra leader. Probably most famous for co-writing "Twist & Shout".

name: Bert Russell
comments: Songwriter, who made a serious attempt at becoming a recording artist in his own right, performing under several pseudonyms.

name: Ozzy Osbourne
comments: English singer, songwriter and TV-personality. He rose to prominence during the 1970s as the lead vocalist of the heavy metal band Black Sabbath.

name: Maurice Gibb
comments: Maurice Gibb was a singer, songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and record producer who achieved fame as a member of the group Bee Gees. He was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1994 and into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1997, as performer (Bee Gees).

name: Barry Mann
comments: Best known as a songwriter, he has also recorded. He wrote many songs together with his wife Cynthia Weil. In 1987 he was inducted with his wife into the Songwriters Hall of Fame and they received the 2011 Johnny Mercer Award for their high quality of songwriting.

name: Cynthia Weil
comments: Songwriter, who wrote many songs together with her husband Barry Mann. In 1987 she was inducted with her husband into the Songwriters Hall of Fame and they received the 2011 Johnny Mercer Award for their high quality of songwriting.

name: Buddy Holly
comments: Rock 'n' roll singer, songwriter and guitarist; inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1986

name: Norman Petty
comments: Record producer, pianist, organist, music publisher and songwriter. He led the nationally successful Norman Petty Trio which included Vi Petty, his wife. Petty built a recording studio in Clovis, New Mexico where he produced and recorded Roy Orbison, Waylon Jennings, Buddy Holly and many others.

name: Trevor Horn
comments: Pop music producer, songwriter, musician and singer

name: Bruce Woolley
aliases: Bruce Woolley and The Camera Club

name: Norman Whitfield
comments: Songwriter and producer credited as one of the creators of the Motown sound.

name: Barrett Strong
comments: Best known as a songwriter, Strong had the first hit for Motown with "Money (That's What I Want)".

name: Bobby Miller
comments: Soul singer, songwriter and producer, first for Chess and later for Motown. Miller is probably best known for his work with The Dells .

name: Bernard Edwards
comments: Bassist and co-founder of the 1970s disco group Chic, together with Nile Rodgers. He died of pneumonia in Japan after a reunion concert "Chic Live at the Budokan" for Japanese TV to celebrate Nile Rodgers' work as a record producer.

name: Nile Rodgers
comments: Guitarist, songwriter and producer. He is a leading light for the disco scene in the late 1970s and recorded as part of Chic and with bandmate Bernard Edwards, produced many of the most popular and memorable disco hits of the 1970s and 1980s. Rodgers is also the first African American to own his own national music distribution company, Sumthing Else MusicWorks, Inc., which is a leader in the distribution of video game soundtracks.

name: Mase
comments: Rapper, songwriter, executive producer and ordained minister

name: Norman Gimbel
comments: Prolific lyricist, who was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1984.

name: Charles Fox
comments: Pop songwriter and composer of music for television and film.  Fox has won two Emmys and a Grammy and been nominated for both the Academy Award and the Golden Globe Award.  He was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 2004.

name: Bukka White
comments: Delta blues guitarist and singer from northeastern Mississippi

name: Jean-Michel Rivat
comments: Lyricist, composer, singer and producer, born in Vesoul, France Long time collaborator of Frank Thomas and of Yves Dessca

name: Eddie Cooley
aliases: Eddie Cooley and The Dimples with Orchestra
comments: Atlanta born singer and songwriter based in NYC

name: Howard Greenfield
comments: Openly gay songwriter, Greenfield died at age 49 from complications of AIDS.  In 1991, Greenfield was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame.

name: George Terry
comments: Blues rock and rock and roll guitarist.

name: Jimmy Jam
comments: R&B songwriter, pianist, keyboardist, programmer and producer

name: Terry Lewis
comments: R&B songwriter, producer, bassist, percussionist and synth programmer

name: Ernst van Altena
comments: Poet, author, translator and lyricist, specialized in adapting French chansons.

name: Jean Corti
comments: Accordionist and composer, born in Bergamo, Italy. Best known as the accompanist of Jacques Brel (1960 - 1966).

name: François Rauber
comments: Pianist, composer, arranger and conductor known for his works with chansonnier Jacques Brel.

name: Stephen Bray
comments: Songwriter, drummer and record producer who owns and operates Saturn Sound recording studios and the Soultone Records label

name: Leadbelly
comments: His date of birth is uncertain: According to his grave he was born in 1889, and according to his 1942 draft registration card the date was  January 23, 1889. However, the 1900 United States Census lists him born in January 1888. Inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1970

name: Otis Blackwell
comments: He is a pianist, singer and songwriter, who was both inducted into the Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1986 and into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1991.

name: Pee Wee Marquette
comments: Pee Wee Marquette was the 3 foot 9 inch announcer and MC at Birdland, the famous NYC nightclub. He can be heard on the intros to countless classic live Jazz records from the 1950s and 1960s.

name: Leroy Bonner
comments: Leroy 'Sugarfoot' Bonner played guitar and sang with The Ohio Players.

name: Ralph Middlebrooks
comments: Ralph 'Pee Wee' Middlebrooks played sax and trumpet with The Ohio Players.

name: Thom Bell
comments: Composer, arranger, conductor, producer and multi-instrumentalist

name: William Hart
comments: Lead vocalist, songwriter and founding member of The Delfonics

name: Roger Waters
comments: Bass player, singer, percussionist and composer

name: David Gilmour
comments: Multi-instrumentalist (mainly guitar), vocalist and songwriter. Best known for his Pink Floyd membership, but also acclaimed for his solo work.

name: The Applicators
comments: All-female pop-punk group formed in Austin, Texas

name: The Dead Milkmen
comments: Comedic punk band from Philadelphia. Formed in 1983.

name: Dark Meat
comments: Horn-heavy southern rock played by rotating cast of up to 15 band members. From Athens, Georgia.

name: School of Seven Bells
comments: Indie rock, dream pop and shoegaze band from New York

name: Shampoo [IT]
comments: Beatles impersonators who sang in Neapolitan dialect.

name: Joe & Eddie
comments: Gospel-folk duo consisting of Joe Gilbert and Eddie Brown, who sang tenor and baritone respectively. The group was quite popular in the early and mid-1960s, and made frequent appearances on television during the course of their time together. Gilbert was killed in an automobile accident on August 6, 1966, while driving home from a gig.

name: The Crust Brothers
comments: Band formed by Stephen Malkmus and members of Silkworm (Michael Dahlquist, Tim Midgett and Andy Cohen), which released one album - Marquee Mark - a live recording.

name: Silkworm
comments: Indie rock band from Missoula, MT, ceasing on the death of drummer Michael Dahlquist

name: Michael Dahlquist
comments: Drummer and songwriter.  He was killed in an automobile crash when a woman seeking to commit suicide rear-ended the vehicle he was in while it was stopped.  The crash killed two other people in the same car as Dahlquist.  The woman whose suicide attempt killed the trio served 3 years in prison.

name: Tim Midgett
comments: Rock bassist, guitarist, vocalist and songwriter.

name: Andy Cohen [US1]
comments: Finger-style guitarist who plays folk, blues and roots music. Cohen also sings.

name: Linda Hopkins
aliases: Linda Hopkins and Her Black & Blue Quartet

name: Eva O
comments: Goth, death-rock and black-metal vocalist and guitarist.

name: Diatribe
comments: Industrial band based in San Jose, California

name: Xorcist
comments: Darkwave and industrial solo project by musician Bat [dj/vj] aka Peter Stone.

name: Skrew
comments: Industrial metal band. Formed in 1990; disbanded in 1998.

name: Timothy Wiles
comments: Electro artist from Anaheim, California. Death Method is his EBM/industrial project.

name: Jay McShann
comments: Swing, mainstream jazz, and blues pianist, singer and leader

name: Tom Collier
comments: Ppercussionist, but also credited for keyboards and drum programming.

name: Tomatito
comments: Flamenco guitarist. Won a Latin Grammy in the category 'Best Flamenco Record' in 2006.

name: The Brandywine Singers
comments: Folk music band founded by a group of University of New Hampshire students. Members include twin brothers, Ron and Ric Shaw, Dave Craig, Fred Corbett and Hal Brown.

name: The Star Spangled Washboard Band
comments: Jug band based in Albany, New York

name: Bobbi Martin
comments: Country and pop music singer, songwriter, and guitarist

name: Dave Holland
comments: Jazz double bassist and composer.  Holland has lived in the United States since 1969.

name: Acid Reign
comments: Thrash metal band. Formed in 1985; dissolved in 1991 and reformed in 2015.

name: Clay People
comments: Industrial rock band based in Albany, New York.

name: Apolitiq
comments: EBM band based in San Pedro, California.

name: Skitzo [1]
comments: Thrash Metal band from Santa Rosa, California

name: Audra
comments: Post-punk / alternative rock band formed in Mesa, Arizona by brothers Bret and Bart Helm

name: In the Nursery
comments: Electronica band known for their cinematic sound. It's based around twin brothers Klive and Nigel Humberstone.

name: Harvey Danger
comments: Alt rock band based in Seattle

name: Martyr Colony
comments: Industrial band formed in Columbus, Ohio in 1988.

name: Virus 23
comments: Industrial band. Formed in 1991; dissolved in 1996.

name: Infam
comments: Synthpop duo now reduced to a solo project of Andre Geisler.

name: Nova [NL]
comments: Electronic music group, who reached the #1 position in the Dutch charts in 1982 with the instrumental "Aurora".

name: Cross Country
comments: Pop group with three former members of The Tokens.

name: Svend Asmussen
aliases: Svend Asmussen and His Dancing Strings
Svend Asmussen und seine beschwingten Zaubergeigen
comments: Jazz violinist, composer and band leader

name: Anthony Monn
comments: Singer, composer and record producer, who achieved his greatest international success with French disco queen Amanda Lear

name: The Golden Palominos
comments: Musical project by Anton Fier and Bill Laswell with an inconstant line-up

name: The Cat Empire
comments: Soul, funk, reggae and latin music crossover band. Founded as a trio initially, their line-up these days includes six members plus a horn section.

name: Clare Bowditch
comments: Musician, actor, radio presenter and business entrepreneur.

name: Penetration
comments: Punk band. Formed in 1976; disbanded in 1980; re-formed in 2000.

name: Eddie Hodges
comments: A child actor in the 1950s, who recorded his first record at age 14

name: Kilgore
comments: Heavy metal band from Providence, Rhode Island.

name: Katja Ebstein
comments: Pop vocalist with three appearances in the Eurovision song contest. Later via chansons crossing over to political songs.

name: Charlie Drake
comments: Comedian, actor, writer and singer, specializing in novelty songs.

name: Paul Reubens
comments: Actor, writer and comedian, best known for his character Pee-Wee Herman

name: Dominic Muldowney
comments: British composer, arranger and conductor born in Southampton

name: Dagmar Krause
comments: Singer best known for her work with avant-rock groups including Slapp Happy, Henry Cow, and Art Bears. She is also noted for her coverage of songs by Bertolt Brecht, Kurt Weill and Hanns Eisler. Her unusual singing style makes her voice instantly recognizable and has defined the sound of many of the bands with whom she has worked.

name: The Young Gods
comments: 'Intellectual' electronics and industrial rock crossover band from Geneva integrating loops and reworked samples in their recordings. Later, they turned to more acoustic recordings and performances.

name: The Gamblers
comments: Surf band led by guitarist-songwriter Derry Weaver. Their best known single was the 1960 instrumental "Moon Dawg", sometimes regarded as the first surf music single.

name: The Tornadoes [US]
comments: Surf music band from Redlands, California

name: John Willett
comments: Expert on and English translator of Bertolt Brecht's works

name: Akrabu
comments: Acoustic ambient music band. Akrabu began as a solo project by Scorpios Androctonus (Crimson Moon, E.V.P., etc). Originally from California, the project relocated to Europe in 1998 and is now established in Germany.

name: Greetje Kauffeld
comments: Jazz singer. Kauffeld represented the Netherlands in the 1961 Eurovision Song Contest. She has lived in Germany for many years.

name: The Happenings
comments: Originally formed in 1961 as a doo-wop group, The Four Graduates, the members had all just recently graduated from their respective high schools; hence, the band's name.  After release of a few singles that went nowhere, the group changed their name to "The Happenings".

name: Failure to Communicate Studio Artists
comments: Anonymous studio session collective set up by the label of the same name

name: Mr Russia
comments: Indie rock duo from Chicago, Illinois

name: Guy Marchand
comments: Actor, musician, singer, lyricist and writer

name: The Headliners
comments: Roots music duo based in Portland, Oregon.

name: Lauren Marie
comments: Rockabilly / country vocalist from Cape Cod, Massachusetts

name: [Unknown]
comments: This page gathers songs written or composed by specific authors and composers who remain unknown or uncredited individually

name: Rev. J.M. Gates
comments: Pastor of Mount Calvary Baptist Church in Rock Dale Park, Atlanta, Georgia (1914-1941). He was a prolific recording artist whose popularity led to recordings by other African American preachers.

name: John McEuen
comments: Multi-instrumentalist. Founding member of the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band.
Alt rock band based in Norfolk, Virginia.
